My story is long and woven into nearly every part of my life. I have been in and out of hospitals since I was nine years old, often spending entire years in medical settings and at multiple Mayo Clinics. Recently, I finally received diagnoses that make sense of decades of suffering: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, POTS, MCAS, and small fiber neuropathy, each with its own complicated, often debilitating ripple effects.
Even so, I have built a meaningful life as an LCSW. I support people through the hardest and most complex parts of their lives every single day. My work gives me purpose, even on the days when I can barely move, when pain takes over, or when I am leaving one appointment only to go to another. I take enormous pride in what I do because helping people feel seen and understood has always been the heartbeat of my life.
I am also a mother to two young girls who are my entire world. They are the reason I fight so hard for answers, and the reason I want to stay as healthy and present as I can. They deserve a mother who feels well and strong, and I want to show them that even in the hardest moments, we can choose curiosity, resilience, and hope.
Despite having a concierge physician, I currently have twenty-one specialists, endless testing, and no real answers. My labs are ‚Äúnormal,‚Äù but my life is not. I am down to ninety-two pounds. I cannot tolerate food without swelling or vomiting. I have violent allergic reactions while simultaneously testing negative for allergies. I spend hours every day coordinating my own care because I have no choice but to be my own quarterback.
And still, nothing adds up. The picture is incomplete. My doctors do not know how to treat me, and they openly say there is more going on that they cannot yet identify. I am living in the space between what they can measure and what my body is actually experiencing. That space is where people fall through the cracks, and where I refuse to stay.
That is what brought me here.
Functional medicine feels right in my heart because I believe deeply in getting to the root, not dismissing symptoms, not handing someone another referral, not treating patients as puzzles too complicated to solve. My chronic illness journey has reshaped the way I understand health, trauma, resilience, and the connection between the body, the nervous system, and the psyche.
I want to learn how to better support myself, and I want to redirect my wellness and chronic illness coaching skills, alongside my clinical background as an LCSW, toward helping people who feel lost in the medical maze, just as I have for most of my life. I want to help people find answers, empowerment, and a path back to themselves.
This certification is not just another credential. It is a step toward reclaiming my own health and becoming the kind of practitioner I wish I had met years ago. It is aligned with everything I value, including depth, curiosity, compassion, science, and the belief that people deserve comprehensive, root-cause-oriented care.

I have been a nurse practitioner for 25 years. I love taking care of patients, helping to improve their health, well-being and quality of life. Over the years, I've seen the healthcare industry become less and less about patient care and more and more about the bottom line. After practicing as an NP for a few years, I started precepting nurse practitioner students. I truly enjoy teaching patients as well as students. I then decided to go back to school and earned my doctorate of nursing practice with the goal of teaching nurse practitioners to be the next generation of dedicated healthcare providers. I left cardiology for academia after 14 years to teach full time in a graduate family nurse practitioner program. Initially, I loved it. Teaching nurses to advance to the next level, helping them develop into independent healthcare providers was highly fulfilling. Over the 6 years that I remained in academia, my role as professor became less and less about teaching and more and more about committee participation, research, presenting at conferences, increasing exposure for the school and generating revenue through grants and increased enrollment. Sadly, I watched as the quality of program declined. Students were less interested in actual learning, complained about their workload and seemed to expect that the faculty somehow implant the knowledge into their brains without them having to do any work. Their degrees became transactional, bought rather than earned. After a student submitted a complaint to the dean because they emailed my at 2 AM and I hadn't responded by 7 AM on the same day, I decided I'd had enough. I would rather take care of patients who actually appreciated my efforts, so I went back to clinical practice in cardiology. Over the past 5 years, I have truly enjoyed taking care of patients, educating them, supporting them and helping to improve their quality of life. I receive great feedback and appreciation from my patients, often commenting on how I listen to them, explain things and take time with them that no other provider does. This is the part that I enjoy the most; making my patients feel heard and figuring out what is going on with them when other providers run a test then tell them, "well, it's not your heart" and dismiss them, leaving them with even more questions than they had before. This method, however, comes at a cost. I am constantly falling behind on documentation, staying late at work and bringing work home. My ADHD medications no longer seem to work. Self-care is non-existent. I am exhausted and my time off is spent worrying about trying to catch up, mindlessly watching tv, listening to audiobooks or doing Sudoku and avoiding going out unless necessary. I have no motivation and do not feel like myself. Something needs to change. I still want to take care of patients and teach, but I don't want to sacrifice the quality of care/education that I provide in order to do paperwork.

column1: Hi, Sarah! It is a pleasure to meet you! First, a big thank you for this opportunity! I'd like to introduce myself by telling you my story. I am an immigrant and came to the US when I was three. I joined the Navy right out of high school as a medic. I've always wanted to be a healer, even back then. After five years, I was at a major crossroads. Do I continue being in the military for another 15 years or do I do something else? Now, I originally wanted to be a doctor - that was my goal...but after considering the price and the time investment, I decided that I would pursue nursing, instead. So, I went to the local community college, which has a reputation as being one of the best in Southern California - and the entire country! It was tough, and for it "only" being an associates degree, it took a LOT longer than anticipated! I graduated in December of 2011 and have been working as a registered nurse since. I have worked in hospice, skilled nursing at a SNF and transitional care/rehab, LTAC, acute care, and now case management. I would like to tell you that I'm satisfied with the choice that I made...but that wouldn't be honest. I'm burnt out a lot of the time trying to care for people, and that affects me in my home life. My wife worked as a unit secretary for a SNF and now works as a financial records specialist at a hospice, so she knows nurses. It's ok, it pays the bills. But it is SOOO stressful!! I ended up being forced to take a year off beginning in December 20th of 2020. The reason? I found out that I had brain cancer, with an aggressive form called "Glioblastoma Multiforme." If you look that type of cancer up, it has a dismal survival rate of about 10%. My wife panicked - big time. Thank God it was operable! If it wasn't...well, I don't know if you would be reading this right now. I'm not exaggerating when I say that it was a wild ride, and I give ALL the credit to God for saving me! Evidently, He still wants me around to do more good on this planet. Unfortunately, as a result of taking so much time off work, I have accrued some pretty hefty debt that we are paying off and will likely continue to for the next decade. The past five years have really shown me just how broken the modern western medicine model really is! The response to the Covid-19 pandemic was HORRENDOUS in my personal opinion. It wasn't the virus that was killing people. It was the loneliness and depression that was induced by the lockdowns. It was loved ones dying alone at a nursing home. It were the poor students whose grades plummeted because they were not learning at the school in person! That was the line in the sand, when it finally hit me. I'm not helping people like I want to be! I see the same patient get readmitted, for the SAME reason, for the THIRD time! What are we as nurses doing to ensure that person does not end up back into our Emergency Department? No more!!! I have always believed in functional medicine and I HATE the modern Western medicine, big-pharma profiteering, a pill for every ill, SICK-care instead of ACTUAL HEALTH-care model!! I want EVERYONE to have abundant health!! I admire naturopaths that have been using herbs and plants to heal people, and it's worked for millennia! But I realize, too, that we do need SOME pharmaceuticals, too. Over the past 30 years, we have seen an exponential explosion in chronic diseases in our country - most of which I believe were preventable!! And it has caused wide-spread suffering and death! So, that is why I am so PASSIONATE about doing this! I want to be a HEALER, not just someone pushing pills at the bedside, or arguing with an insurance company on why patient needs such-and-such services! That's my story, Sarah. I wanted to write more, but I think for now, this should suffice. God bless you and your family this holiday season!
